text: Adds or generates noise in geometry attributes.

The Attribute Noise SOP provides a simple interface for quickly adding coherent noise
to
attributes, without needing to create VOP networks or write VEX code. All of the models provided by the

can be
used with this node.
While this node has a simple and straightforward interface, the following nodes might allow for a finer control over modifying common attributes such as:
If an attribute exists, you can overwrite or combine the noise with the current values according to the
parameter. If an attribute doesn’t exist, this node will create it.
The subset of the input geometry to apply the modifications to. Leave this blank to affect all elements.  The type of the group is controlled by the
Blends between the incoming attribute and the output attribute value. A blend of
means that no adjustment takes place: the incoming attribute value is the output value. Likewise, a value of
will output the adjusted value, ignoring the initial value. Blending can be done either by uniform value (
(when the menu on the right of this parameter is set to
A float attribute between the range
to use as blend value. This attribute must be present on the appropriate elements (as set by
means that no adjustment takes place: the incoming attribute value is the output value. Likewise, a value of
will output the adjusted value, ignoring the initial value.
Choose whether the attributes are float attributes or vector attributes. The node will switch to generate 1D or 3D noise according to this choice.
The name of the attribute to generate noise into. The class of attribute (such as point, face, or vertex) is controlled by the
parameter. If the attribute does not exist, this node will create it. You can specify a space-separated list of names to add noise to multiple attributes at once.

When the attributes are vector attributes, specifies which vector components will be changed by this node. This filter applies as the last step on the adjustment value generation and it is useful to limit the dimension of the noise.
The level at which to look for/create the listed attributes: detail (whole geometry), primitives (faces), points, or vertices.
When the attributes are vector attributes, and the checkbox is on, the direction of the noise will be controlled by the
parameter and the noise will change the length of this vector. This is useful when you need to displace geometry along it’s normal direction.
The attribute to use to specify the direction of the generated noise when
is enabled. By default it will displace the geometry along it’s normal vector.
How to compute the minimum and maximum noise values. This menu lets you quickly set up common ranges (from zero to N, or from -N to N).
The range contains all values between
, the minimum and maximum limits of the range will be
The range contains all values between
, the minimum and maximum limits of the range will be
Behavior in this mode is different from

on
            the attribute adjust nodes, where the resultant interval spans from
How to combine the generated noise with an existing attribute value. If the target attribute does not exist on the input geometry, this menu is ignored.
If the attribute doesn’t exist, set its value. If the attribute does already exist, don’t modify it.
Add the generated noise value to the existing value.
Subtract the generated noise value from the existing value.
Multiply the generated noise value by the existing value.
Use the lower of the generated noise value and the existing value.
Use the higher of the generated noise value and the existing value.
, the generated noise is from 0 to this value. When
, the generated noise is from the negative of this value to 0 value. When
, the generated noise is from negative this value to positive this value.

, sets the length of the custom range.
Per Component button for separate the range along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the

When this is on, the distribution of values is non-uniform, being more likely to fall near the center of the range than the edges. When this is off, values have a more uniform distribution across the range.
This example shows noise where the
is animated. The left side has this parameter on, the right side has this parameter off.
Turn this on to shape the output of the noise with a ramp.

is on, this ramp lets you control the output of the noise function. The horizontal axis represents the range (minimum on the left, maximum on the right). The vertical axis represents the number to output when the noise function generates that point within the range.
The default ramp (diagonal from bottom-left to top-right) outputs each number
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
The default. A faster and more interesting variant of Perlin noise.
Sparse Convolution noise is similar to Worley noise. Does not have artifacts at grid points.
Produces a bumpy output. Named for its alleged resemblance to alligator skin.
A noise where the visual details are the same size.
A noise that’s stable over time, like a rotated Perlin noise, useful to create noise that seems to swirl and flow smoothly across time. Use the
parameter below to control the rotation.
A noise similar to Perlin but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Produces cellular features similar to plant cells, ocean waves, honeycombs, cratered landscapes, and so on.
A variant of Worley noise that produces blunted and cornered features.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
The node generates values for each element by sampling a noise field at the location specified by this vector attribute on the incoming geometry. If this is
(point position, the default), the points of the geometry will appear to swim through the noise. If you want the noise to
to the points, you can copy the initial point positions into a
attribute and use that attribute here instead.
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Per Component button for separate scales along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
You can animate the noise using an expression such as
here. This is faster to compute than
, but gives the visual effect of
across the noise field, which may or may not be acceptable.
Per Component button for separate additional offsets along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you add the a separate offset along each axis.
Turn this checkbox on to use a VEXpression to override parameters based on arbitrary attribute values.
based on arbitrary attributes on the geometry. The comments in the default snippet (and the
preset in the menu to the right of the editor) show which parameters you can override, currently

to offset the sampling
    location by the value of each element’s

vector attribute. As
    another example, using

will overwrite the incoming
    value with the

attribute: this is effectively the same as

Vary the generated noise with time. Some noise types do not support this feature.
Applying animation this way on geometries with millions of element count is slower to compute than using expressions such as
is on, this controls the rate of change of the noise pattern.
The fractal controls let you add additional fractal noise on top of the output of the basic noise type.
Does not add any additional noise on top of the basic noise.
Adds pseudo-random noise on top of the basic output.
but dampens the noise in the valleys, which can be useful for generating mountainous terrain.
Like terrain, but with more sharpness in the valleys.
The following parameters are available when Fractal type is anything except
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The frequency increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. Note that you can use a negative value.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
to the basic noises by warping the noise space.
Controls base feature size of the generated noise. The value applies to each axis.
Widens the peaks or valleys of the noise output.
Accumulates the warp for each iteration (octave) of added fractal noise. This can add interesting smudgy effects when used in images, and interesting landmarks when used for terrain.
Accumulates the warp for each iteration (octave) of added fractal noise.
, this controls the rotation of the
. Because this parameter is fractional, you can’t just use
to animate it, since all integral values will look the same, representing a complete revolution. Instead, try something like
Clamp the lower end of the generated noise values.
When the checkbox is on, clamp values so they are never less than this value, after noise is applied. For vector attributes, the node applies this minimum to all components.
Clamp the higher end of the generated noise values.
When the checkbox is on, clamp values so they are never greater than this value, after noise is applied. For vector attributes, the node applies this maximum to all components.
, turn this on to normalize the output values so they all have the same length (

title: Attribute Noise
summary: Adds or generates noise in geometry attributes.
